description.narrative: SELP project provides technical assistance to support the institutional development of the Election Commission of Pakistan, the Senate and the KP and Balochistan Provincial Assemblies.

participating-org.narrative: SWISS AGENCY FOR DEVELOPMENT AND COOPERATION - SDC
UNITED STATES AGENCY FOR INTERNATIONAL DEVELOPMENT (USAID)

condition.narrative: Social and environmental sustainability will be enhanced through application of the UNDP Social and Environmental Standards (http://www.undp.org/ses) and related Accountability Mechanism (http://www.undp.org/secu-srm).
UNDP as the Implementing Partner will comply with the policies, procedures and practices of the United Nations Security Management System (UNSMS.)

description.narrative: 1.1: Extent to which the ECP's institutional capacity is enhanced 1.2: Extent to which the ECP delivers improved electoral administration. 1.3: Extent to which the ECP engages constructively with stakeholders especially women. 2.1: Extent to which legislative institutions actively engage with the SDGs/development processes 2.2: Extent to which the technical skills of legislators and Secretariat staff are enhanced. 2.3: Extent to which parliamentary institutions are prepared to function during crisis/emergency situation 3.1: Number of citizens reached through civic literacy initiatives (m/f) 4.1: Number of case studies produced by journalist trained under training for media professionals

comment.narrative: 1.1: Scale 2 (Very partially) 1.2: Scale 2 (Very partially) 1.3: Scale 2 (Very partially) 2.1: Scale 2 (Very partially) 2.2: Scale 2 (Very partially) 2.3: Scale 2 (Very partially: Limited awareness and preparedness) 3.1: 0 (Number of citizens reached through civic literacy initiatives) 4.1: 0 (Number of case studies produced by journalist trained under training for media professionals)

1.1: Scale 3 (Partially) (Electoral Management Course, BRIDGE trainings, and other workshops, courses and capacity development interventions conducted for election officials; Support to Federal Election Academy provided; PWDs accessibility assessment initiative conducted) 1.2: Scale 3 (Partially) (Support to the ECPs integration of technology into election administration. Support to the training of election officials for 2019 electoral events) 1.3: Scale 3 (Partially) (Training initiative for young women on election process conducted, Public outreach and voter information exercise conducted for 2019 electoral events; Support provided to ECPs Women NIC Registration Campaign) 2.1: Scale 3 (Partially) (Supported Provincial TFs for enhanced working relationship with standing committees on SDGs; Organized Exchange Program of TFs with other provincial and Federal TFs; Supported TF for holding meetings with government departments; Assisted provincial assembly to establish SDGs resource and research facility) 2.2: Scale 3 (Partially) (Support provided for establishment of Young Parliamentarians’ Forum (YPF) at KP Assembly; National Conference on youth and peace-building organized; Knowledge-sharing workshops conducted for Committee-chairs, WPCs, Minority Caucuses, and Secretariat officials; Legislative support provided to Minority Caucus and WPC, pilot Parliamentary Roadshow conducted) 3.1: 14,000 (M: 11,000, F: 3,000) (Number of citizens reached through civic literacy initiatives) 4.1: 80 (Number of case studies produced by journalist trained under training for media professionals)

1.1 Scale 3: During the reporting period, UNDP/SELP held one Electoral Management Course, involving thirty participants, spanning over a period of 6 weeks. Moreover, three BRIDGE modules; one on Legal Framework, one Political Finance, and the third one on the topic of Gender and Elections have also been carried out, attended by thirty participants.
1.2 Scale 3: UNDP/SELP supported in updating the Election Results Management System. Assistance in training of election officials of erstwhile FATA under Federal Elections Academy (FEA) was also carried out.
1.3 Scale 3: UNDP/SELP carried out public outreach activities in newly-merged districts during Provincial Assembly elections in July 2019. The activities were also carried out during by-election in different constituencies across the country. The project also continued women NIC and voter registration campaigns during the reporting year. Outreach interventions for voter verification through ECP’s Display Centers also carried out across the country.
2.1 Scale 3: UNDP carried out a special session for chairpersons of standing committees of KP Assembly in November, which also included an SDGs-focused segment as a key highlight in which the purpose of Task Force was also explained to the committee chairpersons. Moreover, UNDP/SELP also organized an exposure visit of KP Assembly Task Force to the provincial assembly of Balochistan where the Task Forces of both the Assemblies interacted and shared ideas with each other with a view to learn many good practices in place in their respective houses.
2.2 Scale 3: (UNDP/SELP successfully lobbied with and supported the provincial assemblies of Balochistan and Khyber Pakhtunkhwa for establishing Young Parliamentarians’ Forums. The National Conference on Youth is scheduled for February 2020. Moreover, various specific knowledge-sharing workshops were conducted for Committee Chairs, WPCs and Secretariat officials with a view to increase the knowledge base of the target audience on the specific subjects. In August, a knowledge-sharing workshop for Balochistan Assembly Committee Chairs was held at Pakistan Institute for Parliamentary Services (PIPS) in Islamabad during which a visit to the Senate of Pakistan was also held which resulted in a fruitful interaction with the Chairman Senate.
3.1 The total number of citizens reached out through civic literacy initiative during the reporting period involving UNVs is as follows: In total, 34,814 people were reached out across the country in which approximately 19,447 were males, whereas 15,314 were females. The total number also includes 53 transgenders.
4.1 The activity involving journalists’ training covering KP Assembly is scheduled for January 2020.

1.1 3: Adequate Capacity (Adequate processes/capacity development plan/training modules/trained staff exist) 1.2 3: Adequate (Adequate administrative processes/training plans/training modules/trained staff exist) 1.3 3: Moderately (Engagement strategies/mechanicisms exist and implemented, Gender strategy/gender-centric initiatives exit and implemented) 2.1 3: Partially (Basic understanding of SDGs and partial engagement with SDGs/development processes) 2.2 3: Partially: Basic understanding of legislative mechanisms/processes 2.3: 3 : Partial: Basic awareness and preparedness 3.1 16,000 (M: 12,000, F: 4,000) 4.1 0 training session

1.1. Scale 3: UNDP/SELP enhanced the ECP’ institutional capacity by providing support for the development of a) mandate, scope and framework for the Federal Election Academy (FEA) b) trained 32 ECP officials on ‘Activity Planning’, developed finalized activity plans at the wing level for effective implementation of ECP’s Strategic Plan and developed monitoring tools for activities c) trained 27 ECP officials on Protection against Harassment of Women at the Workplace Act 2010 d) reached out to over 92 million Pakistanis for a voter verification process e) published a legally mandated Annual Report to Parliament f) held discussions on the development of a Gender Mainstreaming and Social Inclusion Framework
1.2. Scale 3: (the prerequisite for the electoral events are complete). However, the electoral administrationn will take place during the local government elections, which are yet to be held next year): UNDP/SELP supported the ECP a) to develop training materials for Boundary Delimitation in Punjab, Khyber Pakhtunkhwa and Sindh and for the Local Government Elections in Punjab and Khyber Pakhtunkhwa (KP) and for the Cantonment Board Elections b) to train 21 ECP officials at FEA for the boundary delimitation process in Punjab, Khyber Pakhtunkhwa and Sindh and 229 delimitation committee members of Punjab and KP c) to train 47 officials for the LG elections in Punjab to carry out their election duties d) to develop Sops for LG electoral process.In addition, UNDP provided support to the Punjab Local Government Department in the preparation of rules for the upcoming LG elections. 1.3. Scale 3: (partially achieved as due to covid 19 NADRA offices were closed and their registration vans were grounded. The gender mainstreaming strategy has been initiated and is in progress): The project continued to support the nationwide joint ECP-NADRA Womens NIC and Voter Registration Campaign to reduce the gender gap between males and females on the electoral roll. UNDP/SELP supported the ECPs implemention of the Campaign in partnership with Trust for Democractic Education and Accountability in 85 districts, which has a network of member organizations across Pakistan. UNDP/SELP registered 132,715 women for their NICs and to become voters. UNDP/SELP ensured ECPs constructive engagement with stakeholders, and partners at the national, provincial and districts levels. UNDP/SELP in collaboration with TDEA also conducted a media campaign to the support this campaign.Additionally, UNDP/SELP held discussions with the ECPs Gender unit for the development of a Gender Mainstreaming and Social Inclusion Framework.
2.1.Scale 3: The project mobilized lawmakers of Balochistan and Khyber Pakhtunkhwa (KP) Assemblies throuh establishing and supporting SDGs Task Forces. With UNDP/SELP support, the MPs established linkages with different departments of the provincial governments and as a result, multiple briefing sessions were (3 in the reporting year) held in which 12 senior officials of relevant branches of the executive were invited to brief the lawmakers about the progress on various SDG-related schemes/projects in addition to explaining the challenges for the lawmakers could take up the matter in the Assembly session to address those. 2.2. Scale 3: UNDP/SELP organised various trainings and capacity-building events for lawmakers and Secretariat staff of the Balochistan and KP Assemblies with the focus to enhance their technical skills to enable them to discharge their functions more effectively and efficiently. As a result of such interventions, the Balochistan Assembly Public Accounts Committee (PAC) has been able to lay its first ever report before the House. The unprecedented feat has been achieved after two UNDP/SELP-organised trainings to the staff and Members of the PAC. with 42 participants. Apart from these initiatives, training of trainers, workshop on strengthening of committees, and effective media engagement were also undertaken. 2.3. Scale 3: UNDP/SELP is conducting Business Continuity Assessments studies of the Senate, and the Balochistan and KP Assemblies with a view to enabling the legislative houses to identify issues and challenges related to the legal framework, administrative and IT infrastructure and capacity to function during the times of crisis. Similarly, the project is also developing two separate Guides on the oversight role of committees for Balochistan and KP Assemblies to enable the targeted committees to continue functioning during times of crises such as Covid-19. To this regard, the draft frameworks and consultations with the Secretarit and political leadership of respective assemblies are completed. The project has also provided online tools (in the form of 16 Zoom software licenses) to Balochistan (06 licenses) and KP (05 lincenses) Assemblies and PIPS (05 licenses) to continue working remotely during Covid-19. UNDP/SELP is providing the associated training on the use of technology to hold virtual sessions. The partner institutions have already started using the software tools for holding meetings and organising remote trainings. 3.1. Yes-UNDP SELP recruited United Nations Youth Volunteers in each of Paksitans four provinces to conduct voter and civic education activites at the rural grassroots level. These UNVs conducted 947 civic awareness initaitives, reaching 425,247 people (F: 17,345, M: 21,151, T: 34, Misc: 386,717) through direct and online platforms. The project continued to support the joint ECP-NADRA Womens NIC and Voter Registration Campaign to reduce the gender gap on the electoral roll. Over 95,286 individuals were directly reached through 3,586 stakeholder and mobilization activities. The media Campaign through Radio and Television reached out to 86.2 miilion people. This UNDP support attributed to the registration of over 1.8 million women.Additionally, to support the ECP for the voter verification process an outreach campaign through radio and television reached out to 92.25 million people. 4.1. No Target for the year 2020

1.1 Scale Item 3: Adequate Capacity (Adequate processes/capacity development plan/training modules/trained staff exist) 1.2 Scale Item 3: Adequate (Adequate administrative processes/training plans/training modules/trained staff exist) 1.3 No target. 2.1 No target. 2.2 No target. 2.3 Scale Item 3: Partial: Basic awareness and preparedness 3.1 18,000 (M:13,000, F:5,000) 4.1 No target.

1.1. Scale 3: UNDP/SELP provided technical assistance and quality assurance to the ECP for the development of its legally mandated Annual Report to Parliament submitted in March 2021. UNDP/SELP supported the ECP in the development and printing of outreach materials related to COVID-19 SOPs for bye elections. UNDP/SELP provided 130 banners and 450 posters, and it is estimated that the number of voters reached through this material was 69,500 voters of which 35,445 were men and 34,055 were women. UNDP/SELP supported the ECP to develop a public outreach video message for International Women’s Day (IWD) by the Chief Election Commissioner (CEC), which was uploaded on the ECP’s website, Facebook page and included as news tickers on key television channels. In his message, the CEC reiterated ECP’s commitment for inclusive electoral processes for women and all segments of society, including minorities, persons with disabilities and transgenders.UNDP/SELP is providing ongoing technical support to the ECP for a pre-service course for newly recruited election officers. This support is with respect to development of materials, detailed training and execution plans, quality assurance, monitoring/evaluation tools and facilitation during the upcoming course.UNDP/SELP revised and shared the draft Women’s NIC and Voter Registration Campaign Phase IV continuation document for the sustainability and continuation of the ECP-NADRA Campaign, while taking into account lessons learned and recommendations from previous phases of the Campaign.
1.2 Scale 3: UNDP led technical assistance to the ECP as related to its implementation of the Senate elections at the Federal and Provincial levels. With the support of UNDP/SELP, the ECP developed a Senate Election Handbook for election officials, and a guide for the members of parliament and provincial assemblies. Additionally, UNDP/SELP provided technical assistance to the ECP to successfully conduct two 3-day trainings for ROs and Polling Officers with a pool of 46 ECP’s officers (M:42, F:04) and a pre-election refresher training with a trained pool of 31 ROs and Polling Officers (M: 29, F:2). UNDP/SELP provided technical assistance to the ECP in the planning and production of training materials for the trainings of delimitation committees and election officials as related to local government and cantonment board elections. UNDP/SELP supported the Local Government Department-Punjab and Provincial Election Commission-Punjab in the drafting of the local government election rules in line with the revised legal framework. 1.3: No target for the year 2.1: No target for the year 2.2: No target for the year 2.3 Scale 3( UNDP/SELP conducted Business Continuity Assessments studies of the Senate, and the Balochistan and KP Assemblies with a view to enabling the legislative houses to identify issues and challenges related to the legal framework, administrative and IT infrastructure and capacity to function during the times of crisis. Similarly, the project developed two separate Guides on the oversight role of committees for Balochistan and KP Assemblies to enable the targeted committees to continue functioning during times of crises such as Covid-19. Additionally, UNDP/SELP provided the associated trainings on the use of technology to hold virtual sessions. 3.1 18,000 (M:13000, M: 5,000)(UNDP/SELP supported the ECP in the development and printing of outreach materials related to COVID-19 SOPs for bye elections. UNDP/SELP provided 130 banners and 450 posters, and it is estimated that the number of voters reached through this material was 69,500 voters of which 35,445 were men and 34,055 were women. 4.1: No target for the year
